bibl.title: Letter from Henry Binley to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 17, 1928

div1.p: Binley writes to Emilie Lawrence Reed regarding a lecture by Peabody on yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Binley to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 17, 1928
div1.opener:
9 Westchester Ave.
White Plains, N. Y.
Feb. 17.1928.
Mrs. Walter Reed
Washington, D. C.
Dear Madam:
div1.p:
Just a few lines to let you know that
I have recently had the pleasure of listening to a
very interesting illustrated talk of our fellow citizen
Prof. Jas. E. Peabody on the subject of Yellow Fever.

I was indeed chagrined to learn that so
little had been done by our Government, for the heroes
who so valiantly offered their lives in the prosecution
of so great and so wonderfully successful an undertaking

Personally I can do but little in making up
for our government inadequacy; but I do wish in
this letter to assure you of my personal appreciation
of such heroism as was shown by your husband.

I am glad movements are being made
calling upon our government to adequately show
its appreciation of such heroic services.
